questiontext.text: In the Sales & Demand Planning pipeline, what is the primary goal of the SEE phase on the weekly sales data?

answer.text: Generate a 3-week moving average forecast for each SKU.

feedback.text: Not quite. Forecasting is done after SEE, not during the initial data understanding.

answer.text: Decide the final replenishment quantity to order.

feedback.text: No. Replenishment decisions come after we understand and clean the data.

answer.text: Detect structural and value issues such as missing weeks, wrong dtypes, duplicates, and anomalies.

feedback.text: Correct. SEE focuses on surfacing structural and anomaly issues in the raw weekly data.
No. Transport optimisation is a different problem and not the goal of SEE on sales data.

questiontext.text: Why do we group by (SKU, Week_dt) and aggregate Sales_Units, Is_Promo, and Price before reindexing to the full weekly calendar?

answer.text: To collapse multiple rows for the same SKU and week into a single, consistent demand signal.

feedback.text: Correct. Grouping resolves duplicates and produces one clean demand value per SKU per week.

answer.text: To artificially increase the number of records for better model training.

feedback.text: No. The goal is to clean duplicates, not to inflate the dataset size.

answer.text: To remove all promo weeks from the dataset.

feedback.text: Incorrect. Promo weeks are kept; we only resolve duplicate rows per SKU and week.

answer.text: To ensure every SKU has exactly the same mean sales.

feedback.text: No. Grouping does not force SKUs to have the same mean; it just aggregates duplicates.

questiontext.text: For a given SKU, average Sales_Units are 100 on non-promo weeks and 140 on promo weeks. What is the promo uplift (%)?

feedback.text: Incorrect. Use (140 − 100) / 100 × 100% to compute uplift.
No. Recalculate the uplift using the change divided by the base demand.
Correct. Promo uplift = (140 − 100) / 100 × 100% = 40%.
Incorrect. That would overstate the effect; the correct uplift is 40%.

questiontext.text: What is the main difference between MAPE and Forecast Bias when evaluating the moving average forecast?

answer.text: MAPE measures only over-forecasting, while Bias measures only under-forecasting.

feedback.text: No. Both metrics can reflect over- and under-forecasting in different ways.

answer.text: MAPE is computed in units, while Bias is computed in percentages.

feedback.text: Incorrect. MAPE is a percentage error; Bias can be defined in units or percentages.

answer.text: They are the same metric with different names.

feedback.text: No. MAPE and Bias capture different aspects of forecast performance.

answer.text: MAPE measures average percentage error magnitude, while Bias measures systematic over- or under-forecasting.

feedback.text: Correct. MAPE focuses on error size, whereas Bias shows consistent over- or under-forecasting.

questiontext.text: In our simple replenishment logic, Safety_Stock = z · weekly_std. Which change will most directly reduce the safety stock requirement for a SKU?

feedback.text: No. Raising the forecast does not directly reduce safety stock in this formula.

answer.text: Reducing the weekly demand variability (lower weekly_std).

feedback.text: Correct. Safety stock scales with weekly_std, so lower variability reduces safety stock for the same service level.

answer.text: Shortening the historical time window from 26 to 4 weeks.

feedback.text: Not necessarily. Changing the window length does not guarantee a lower weekly_std.
Incorrect. More promotions usually increase variability and can increase safety stock needs.
